question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute \[
\left\lfloor \frac{2007! + 2004!}{2006! + 2005!}\right\rfloor.
\](Note that $\lfloor x \rfloor$ denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.)
inference:
Using Wilson's theorem
$$p-1\equiv 0 \pmod{p}$$
for any prime $p$, we have
$$2006!\equiv-1\pmod{2007},\ \ 2005!\equiv -1\pmod{2006}.$$
Hence,
$$\begin{align} 2007!+2004! &\equiv (-1)+2004! \pmod{2007} \\\ &\equiv (-1)-2005! \pmod{2007} \\\ &\equiv (-1)-(-1) \pmod{2007} \\\ &\equiv 0 \pmod{2007}. \end{align} $$
Similarly,
$$\begin{align} 2006!+2005! &\equiv (-1)+2005! \pmod{2006} \\\ &\equiv (-1)-2006! \pmod{2006} \\\ &\equiv (-1)-(-1) \pmod{2006} \\\ &\equiv 0 \pmod{2006}. \end{align} $$
Therefore,
$$\frac{2007!+2004!}{2006!+2005!}\equiv \frac{0}{0}\pmod{2007},$$
and so,
$$\left\lfloor \frac{2007!+2004!}{2006!+2005!}\right\rfloor=\left\lfloor \frac{0}{0}\right\rfloor=\boxed{0}.$$
Final Answer: $\boxed{0}$. I hope it is correct.
